title: How to Disgorge a Fish

steps.headline: If the fish is small, hold the fish firmly around the dorsal and pectoral fins (Be careful if the fish has perch-like fins).
Slide the disgorger down the line, until the eye or spade of the hook is inserted into the end of the the disgorger.
steps.description: Hold the line tight and move the fish closer to you to help loosen the hook.

steps.headline: If the hook is just stuck into the roof of the fishes mouth, then push down until it releases.
If the hook is very far down (caused by late striking or the fish swallowing the hook) wriggle and tug until it comes loose.
If all else fails and there is no resort, cut or snap your line as far to the hook as possible.
steps.description: This is the kindest thing you can do the help the fish survive.

text: If the fish is small, hold the fish firmly around the dorsal and pectoral fins (Be careful if the fish has perch-like fins).  Gently tighten your line.  Slide the disgorger down the line, until the eye or spade of the hook is inserted into the end of the the disgorger. Hold the line tight and move the fish closer to you to help loosen the hook. If the hook is just stuck into the roof of the fishes mouth, then push down until it releases.  If the hook is very far down (caused by late striking or the fish swallowing the hook) wriggle and tug until it comes loose.  If all else fails and there is no resort, cut or snap your line as far to the hook as possible. This is the kindest thing you can do the help the fish survive.
sentences: If the fish is small, hold the fish firmly around the dorsal and pectoral fins (Be careful if the fish has perch-like fins).
Slide the disgorger down the line, until the eye or spade of the hook is inserted into the end of the the disgorger.
Hold the line tight and move the fish closer to you to help loosen the hook.
If the hook is just stuck into the roof of the fishes mouth, then push down until it releases.
If the hook is very far down (caused by late striking or the fish swallowing the hook) wriggle and tug until it comes loose.
If all else fails and there is no resort, cut or snap your line as far to the hook as possible.
This is the kindest thing you can do the help the fish survive.
